ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Social, political, and environmental topics regarding China and the US.
Better reading skills in Chinese, some improvement in speaking about political and societal topics
learn chinese well - great discussion topics
Learned more chinese vocab and got practice speaking during discussions

Learned a lot about modern Chinese politics. Learned from both a historical and modern point of view. One skill learned was speaking in more debate based discussion. Another skill learned was processing long, scholarly readings. Develop a lot of presentational skills through the many different reports that we gave.
Learned about chinas history and heard other peoples opinion on issues.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very flexible, every student can improve on their own time and through their own methods
Weaknesses: the essays were all more opinion pieces rather than real scholarly material, discussions were a bit shallow

Strengths: survey class and definitely goes over a lot of modern problems that are going on in China. Helps student vocalize their many ideas on modern problems, and makes student more aware of a lot of the important global issues outside of the US. Works a lot on the student's reading abilities. 
Weakness: for students that are not prepared, there will be a lot of vocab in the readings and in discussion. The class could definitely be more interactive, there were times in class where it was mostly just the teacher talking and going over the lesson.

Strength is the class was fun and engaging. The presentations were really interesting.
Weakness is that sometimes I think we spent a little too much time on one topic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Pretty light workload and seminars are pretty discussion-based.
Yes! Fun Chinese course which allows you to improve in your own style as the professor is very flexible and open-minded.
yes, very useful to get advanced exposure to debating

This is a decent upper-level chinese course to take. It has less homework and fewer graded assignments than most other chinese classes. However, if you're not a native or heritage speaker of chinese, this class will probably be much more difficult for you than it is for your classmates, who will mostly be heritage/native speakers. Not necessarily intellectually challenging, but it takes a long time to do the readings.

I would strongly recommend this class to anyone remotely interested in politics and learn about a lot of the fundamental differences between China and US, and believe they have good foundation in reading and speaking Chinese. This class is for you if you are more interested in reading and speaking, both presentational and discussion-based. This class does not go over a lot of writing, but will cover a lot of new vocab if you were not familiar with a lot of more difficult vocab prior.
Yes. This course is a pretty good choice for students who want to practice their speaking skills and learn about chinas development and dilemma.
